descriptionSet.description: An advertisement of Vinoliya White Rose Soap in Urdu and English. The advertisement shows an Indian lady wearing a pink sari who plucks and carries white Indian roses in her basket.

inscription.text: ونولیا وائٹ روز صابن ہندی گلاب کے پھلواری کی تروتازگی لاتا ہے
Vinolia white rose sabun Hindi gulab ke phulwari ki tar-o tazgi lata hai.
Vinolia White Rose soap brings the freshness of an Indian rose.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

titleSet.title: Advertisement for Vinolia White Rose Soap
ونولیا وائٹ روز صابن

hra:item.hra:value: text-ur: ونولیا وائٹ روز صابن ہندی گلاب کے پھلواری کی تروتازگی لاتا ہے
text-transcription-ur: Vinolia white rose sabun Hindi gulab ke phulwari ki tar-o tazgi lata hai.
text-en: Vinolia White Rose soap brings the freshness of an Indian rose.

description-en: An advertisement of Vinoliya White Rose Soap in Urdu and English. The advertisement shows an Indian lady wearing a pink sari who plucks and carries white Indian roses in her basket. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The Urdu text in the advertisement for Vinolia Soap featured in this image loosely translates as “Vinolia White Rose soap brings the freshness of an Indian rose.” While the woman wears a stylish blouse and sari, she seems Caucasian and holds an unmistakably English basket of roses! (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)
related literature: Dyer, Richard and Christine Gledhill 2009. "Wanted: Cultured ladies Only! Female Stardom and Cinema in India 1930s-1950s". Urbana and Chicago: University of Illinois Press. (gs)
related literature: Gadihoke, Sabika 2010. "Selling Soap and Stardom: The Story of Lux", http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/104/index.html, 2010-12-13 (gs)
related literature: McClintock, Anne 2001. “Soft Soaping Empire: Commodity Racism and Imperial Advertising” in Double Crossings: Madness, Sexuality and Imperialism. Vancouver, Canada: Ronsdale. (gs)
related literature: Sivulka, Julianne 1998. "Soap, Sex and Cigarettes: A Cultural History of Advertising". Belmont, California: Wadsworth Publishing Co. (gs)
McClintock, Anne 2001. “Soft Soaping Empire: Commodity Racism and Imperial Advertising” in Double Crossings: Madness, Sexuality and Imperialism. Vancouver, Canada: Ronsdale.

Sivulka, Julianne 1998. "Soap, Sex and Cigarettes: A Cultural History of Advertising". Belmont, California: Wadsworth Publishing Co.
